title.native: 遊☆戯☆王　デュエルモンスターズ

description:
Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters centers around the journey of the spirit of an ancient Egyptian pharaoh who is trying to re-discover who he was many years ago, since he has lost his memories. With the help of a boy, Yugi Mutou, the one who awakened the spirit, and his friends, he battles many villains and adversaries. Many of the villains have been linked to the Nameless Pharaoh's past, due to the Millennium Puzzle he holds and many try to take the puzzle and his power away from him.

The series focuses on the card game aspect of it and the main theme represented throughout the series is friendship.

tags.name: Card Battle
tags.description: Centers around individuals competing in card games.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Proxy Battle
tags.description: A proxy battle is a battle where humans use creatures/robots to do the fighting for them, either by commanding those creatures/robots or by simply evolving them/changing them into battle mode.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Death Game
tags.description: Features characters participating in a game, where failure results in death.

node.description: Younger sister of [Ai Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/95647).

Origin: Kumamoto-ken, Japan 
Genre: J-pop 
Years active: 2001- 
Label(s): Nippon Crown, birdie house inc. - ABSOLUTE PRODUCTION 
Influences: Miyazaki Hayao, Gackt

The creator of Yu-Gi-Oh! He loved playing shogi, mahjong, card games, and tabletop role-playing games.

In an interview with Shonen Jump, Takahashi stated that his favorite manga from other authors included Akira by Katsuhiro Otomo, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure by Hirohiko Araki, and Dragon Ball by Akira Toriyama. He also enjoyed reading American comics, with Hellboy being his favorite American comic book character.

On July 6, 2022, a body in snorkeling gear was found off the coast of Nago City, Okinawa, which was identified the following day as Takahashi. It was revealed by a U.S. Army Officer that Takahashi attempted to aid in the rescue of three people at a riptide in Mermaid's Grotto, Onna, on July 4, 2022.

[Website](http://mitsumune.jp/)

Shinkichi Mitsumune is a Japanese composer who writes music primarily for anime. He graduated from Rikkyo University, College of Economics. From the young age of four, he attended the Yamaha Music School and received acoustic training. He started playing the electronic organ at the age of 10 and received tuition from Koichi Oki - a jazz organist while still in junior high school. While at university, he started playing the keyboard for professional bands following which he joined the band of jazz vocalist, Marlene, and toured various jazz festivals across Japan for about two years.

In 1995, he worked on his first anime soundtrack, [Nurse Angel Ririka SOS](https://anilist.co/anime/616/Nurse-Angel-Ririka-SOS/) in which the profound, high-quality and soothing composition performed with a full orchestra garnered high acclaim. This performance was followed by a string of hit anime soundtracks including [Revolutionary Girl Utena](https://anilist.co/anime/440/Revolutionary-Girl-Utena/), [Yu-Gi-Oh!](https://anilist.co/anime/481/YuGiOh/), The series [Rozen Maiden](https://anilist.co/anime/64/Rozen-Maiden/), [Negima!](https://anilist.co/anime/157/Negima/) (2005), The Series [Zero no Tsukaima](https://anilist.co/anime/1195/The-Familiar-of-Zero/) and [Yu-Gi-Oh! VRAINS](https://anilist.co/anime/98231/YuGiOh-VRAINS/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/takama2_shinji) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高松信司)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/武上純希)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/杉島邦久)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ushimou730) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/馬越嘉彦)

A highly prolific and respected character designer.

Originating from Monsieur Onion, where he spent his in-betweening days studying under [Hirotoshi Takaya](https://anilist.co/staff/117473/) and [Junichi Hayama](https://anilist.co/staff/140660/). In 1991, he moved to Studio Cockpit with [Hisashi Kagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120432/) and [Tatsufumi Tamakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/109607/). A few years later he debuted as a character designer on [Grappler Baki](https://anilist.co/anime/1859/) in 1994.

He is said to be a very fast and efficient worker, and according to himself, he much rather participates in TV productions than theatrical ones. Close friends with [Hiroshi Nagahama](https://anilist.co/staff/99346/) whom he often works with. They first worked together on [Juubei-chan 2](https://anilist.co/anime/636/), for which Umakoshi provided the designs for and served as the chief animation director on all 13 episodes. The following year, the duo teamed up again for [Mushishi](https://anilist.co/anime/457/), which's production quality was unusually high for a TV production. Umakoshi designed the characters and worked as the chief animation director on all 26 episodes of the series and hit a burn-out. After this he took a step back on major roles for a few years. Both him and Nagahama reprised their roles on Mushishi's revival in 2014.

In 2016, Umakoshi was appointed as the character designer on [My Hero Academia](https://anilist.co/anime/21459/), and has since been highly involved with the series' production as both an animation director and animator.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/カサヰケンイチ)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/カサヰケンイチ)
Known to be a fast and efficient worker. Often directing multiple works at a time.

Famous for his depictions of fingers and the "Joey Chin" in Yu-Gi-Oh!.

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/早川啓二)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/平光琢也)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/島村秀一)

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.
Mitsuharu Miyamae is an art director.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/154741/)._
